Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Control in Authoritarian States

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
Why do authoritarian states choose to limit religious freedom? What explains the Chinese Communist Party (CCP)'s decision to repress certain Christian churches while allowing other Christian churches to operate? Currently, the CCP officially permits Christian churches to operate contingent on registration with the government. However, recent accounts reveal that the CCP has repressed both registered and unregistered churches, suggesting that registered churches are not safe from repression, and not all unregistered churches are targets of repression. The CCP's position as both the guarantor and repressor of religious freedom calls into question which aspects of religion the CCP finds permissible or threatening. Despite the broad relevance and timely importance, this topic has remained largely unaddressed due to China's restrictive environment. Through intensive fieldwork in China, this project seeks to explain the thought process behind the CCP's selective treatment of churches, thereby shedding light onto both the Party's broader political objectives and the decentralized decision-making process of the authoritarian state. At a broader level, this project speaks to historical legacies, state-society relations, human rights, and international relations.


Why do authoritarian states choose to limit religious freedom? The CCP's position as both the guarantor and repressor of religious freedom calls into question which aspects of religion the CCP finds permissible or threatening. This project addresses these questions by explaining the variation in the CCP's treatment of Protestant churches in China. It examines how local threats (domestic factors) and the concern for foreign influence (international factors) explain the Party's repression of Protestant churches. Due to China's restrictive environment, studies on this topic have suffered from limits in data collection and research methodology. Through a combination of interviews, surveys, and archival research in China, this project fills this gap by, first, developing a comprehensive, on-the-ground index of government treatment of churches, and second, collecting observations of domestic and international factors that may influence the CCP's treatment of churches. Understanding which churches the government chooses to repress sheds light onto the Party's objectives and the decentralized decision-making process of the authoritarian state. In addition, the project highlights the topic of religion, which itself has often been mistreated and underemphasized in existing political science. This project ambitiously, but justifiably, aims to fill important gaps in literature by building upon existing knowledge and paving new intellectual and methodological roads through intensive field research.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This dissertation project explores the Chinese government's repression of Protestant churches in China. Currently, the Chinese Communist Party (CCP) officially permits five religions, including Protestantism, contingent on registration with the government. Churches that register with the government operate legally but with less autonomy over their operations, while those that do not register operate illegally but with more autonomy. Despite the clear dichotomy between registered and unregistered churches, government repression of churches has varied both across and within these categories. Two puzzles arise. First, why does the CCP both guarantee and repress the religious freedom of Christians? Second, why are not all registered churches safe from repression, and why are not all unregistered churches repressed?

With the support of the National Science Foundation, the researcher has conducted a combination of interviews and surveys of 150 religious leaders and local officials in fifteen Chinese cities. The researcher has found that the manner in which a local official implements religious policies in his or her area of jurisdiction depends on two factors: how the official views the church and how the official views his or her position in relation to other involved actors. More specifically, the official's view of the church determines the church's chance of being repressed. As the church carries more threatening characteristics, such as being involved in political activities or having a sizable congregation, the official sees the need to repress the church. Similarly, as the church serves more useful purposes for the local government, the official is more likely to utilize the church instead of repressing it. Next, the official's view of his or her position in relation to other actors -- namely, the central government, his or her peers, the local population, and international actors -- determines his method of implementing religious policies. Given the church's likelihood of being repressed, these additional calculations modify and finalize the official's decision to carry through with repression.

Using this framework, the project provides an in-depth analysis of how religion is perceived and managed by different levels of government, how their perception gets translated into regulations, and how these regulations are implemented upon, and received by, the religious communities in China. Due to the timeliness of fieldwork, the project is able to capture the change in priorities at the top as they are borne out through the new religious regulations in 2018. Therefore, the research framework explains the implementation of religious policies both before and after the new religious regulations are published.

This research project puts the spotlight on Chinese leadership, its treatment of society, and its outlook on foreign policy at a time when China is taking center stage as a great power and a thriving authoritarian state. Understanding which churches the government chooses to repress sheds light onto the Party's objectives. Furthermore, local policy variations reveal divergent interests and the decentralized decision-making process of the authoritarian state. How China manages its state-society relations can be informative for understanding other authoritarian regimes.

At a broader level, this dissertation project speaks broadly to historical legacies, state-society relations, human rights, and international relations, which are topics of importance in disciplines not limited to political science. Despite the broad relevance and timely importance, the topic has remained largely unaddressed by any single discipline. Amidst the restrictive environment in China, studies on this topic have suffered from limits in data collection and research methodology, producing results that are largely descriptive and apolitical. This project proposes to fill this gap and highlight the concept of religion, which itself has often been mistreated and underemphasized in existing political science. 

Methodologically, religious repression in China is a topic that can only be thoroughly understood through on-site fieldwork. Although this ethnographic approach has been time consuming and difficult, the findings are ever more nuanced and valuable. In sum, this project ambitiously, but justifiably, aims to fill important gaps in literature by building upon existing knowledge and paving new roads through intensive field research.
